content.description:
This is a moderately steep line on smaller holds with two distinct cruxes - one being a bit above the first bolt and the next at the third bolt. This route climbs a lot like

Headstones

in The Catacomb.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel. One 60m will get you down with rope to spare.
content.location:
This is the rightmost route on this wall and is about 15 feet right of

Unknown 8

. Â A very cool and comfortable flat boulder is perfect for belaying, relaxing and enjoying the solitude of the Lion's Den.

content.description:
This climb seemed reminiscent of

Monastic Groove

at the Outer Gates. It has steep climbing on good holds.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor with a twisted quicklink and a Fixe ring hanger for rappel.
content.location:
This route starts about 15' right of

Unknown 7

. It is the middle of three routes on this face. The first bolt is a ways up, but it is easy climbing to get there.

content.description: This has lots of fun climbing on big holds. Just keep climbing up looking for jugs!
content.protection: Eight bolts to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location:
This route is located on the formation across the corridor(north) from the rock which holds routes

Unknown 3

and

Unknown 6

. It's about 200 feet downhill from

Hole in the Wall

. There are three routes on the face. This is the leftmost route.

content.description: Thought provoking climbing leads to the crux at the third bolt. More interesting route finding lead past two more bolts to the top.
content.protection: Five bolts lead to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location:
This route starts about 50 feet downhill from

Unknown 3

. You can see four of the route's five bolts from the ground.

content.description:
This route climbs an interesting protrusion at the start past two bolts and then joins the route

Unknown 4

near its third bolt. To start, traverse in from the left or go up directly(a bit more difficult) to reach the first bolt. It's a long way between the second and third bolts (which looks like it was added after the FA), but the terrain is not difficult.

It's too bad this route didn't follow an independent line up the right side of the arete. The climbing over there looks fun.
content.protection:
5 bolts, the last two are shared with the route

Unknown 4

. This has twisted quicklinks at the top for rappel.
content.location:
Locate a green protrusion/dike about 25 feet downhill (right) of the start of

Unknown 4

.

content.description: This short route climbs on sharp holds and the edge of the arete past 2 bolts where the difficulty eases somewhat.  Three more bolts lead to the anchors.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location:
This route is located on the south side of the gully just uphill from

Unknown 2

and downhill from

Hole in the Wall

in the same gully. It is about 200 feet south of Barnacle Rock. Locate a small pinnacle with a pine tree at its base.

content.description: This is a fun arete climb with a steep crux at the 4th bolt. The rock in this area of the Lion's Den is very crystalline and sharp. Wear and tear on your finger tips may vary.
content.protection: Six bolts to a double bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location:
This route is about 200 feet uphill from

Unknown 2

on the south side of the gully. As another point of reference, it is about 100-200 feet downhill from

Hole in the Wall

on the other side of the same gully.

This is a striking face/arete on the south side of the gully.

Rap 80' to the start.

content.description: The crux of this route is found just above the rappel anchor mid-pitch where some very interesting rock is encountered.
content.protection:
There are 3 bolts to the mid-pitch, two-bolt, rappel anchor then 5 bolts above that to the top of the climb and another two-bolt anchor. You cannot reach the ground with a single 60m rope, so you must use the mid-pitch rappel anchor. This probably also applies to a 70m rope as well.

Both rappel anchors are equipped with twisted 3/8" quicklinks. Be careful how you thread your rope.
content.location:
This route is locate two formations to the right (SE) of Barnacle Rock. It climbs directly up the narrowing face to the end of the obvious difficulties.

There is another route just right of this one. It looks much easier and ends at the same set of anchors.

content.description: This is a steep arete climb on sharp holds. The bolt spacing is probably not for the budding leader, but it's all there. Fun!
content.protection: Six bolts to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks.
content.location:
It is across the small corridor from

Unknown 12

. You could probably belay for both from the same spot.

content.description: Good climbing on positive holds leads to a crux between the fourth and fifth bolts. Those not comfortable at this grade might find this route a bit runout.
content.protection: Five protection bolts to a two bolt anchor with rings for rappel.
content.location: This route is on the formation across the gully to the south from the Hole in the Wall. It climbs the east face of the formation.

content.description: This has no definitive crux, just fun, enjoyable climbing up the arete.
content.protection: Six bolts to a two bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location: This route is on the south end of the formation directly across the gully from Hole in the Wall. It is identified by a sharp arete going south to north.

content.description: This route has steep climbing on big holds with a crux around the 3rd bolt as you climb up and right to gain the arete. Pass the "Eye of the Needle" around the second bolt.
content.protection: There are three bolts on the left side of the arete and four bolts on the arete proper. Rappel from twisted quicklinks on a 60m rope.
content.location:
This route is located about 150 downhill from

Hole in the Wall

on the sharp arete which marks the western end of the wall. It is located about 20 feet uphill from the right edge of the wall which holds the three climbs

Unknown 7

,

Unknown 8

, and

Unknown 9

.

Katie's Route

is in the alcove to the north.

content.description: The hardest moves are climbing past the first bolt.  After that, the difficulty decreases dramatically, but it's still fun climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: Four bolts to a two-bolt anchor with twisted quicklinks for rappel.
content.location: This route is located on the arete just right (east) of Barnacle Rock. It climbs a dark brown face/arete which appears to be fractured into square and rectangular blocks.

content.description: Simply titled, "Offwidth," this climb is to the right of (and shares the anchors with) the simply titled, "Arete." According to Gillet's guidebook, the crux is face climbing alongside the offwidth. Fist-jam until holds can be utilized on either face that the crack splits.
content.protection: Rack up to a #5 Camalot (or TR after doing "Arete").

content.description: Facing the Bearhug is a narrow pillar with a bolted line up the checkered face. Lion's Mane climbs the flakey hand crack on the left side.
content.protection: Rack up to a 3.5 Friend.
content.location: Upon walking into the Lion's Den, walk right around the second pillar.

content.description: This is a finely featured gem and a great moderate route. Downhill from Hole in the Wall, find a bushy gully with scrambling hinting of the climb to come. KC ascends the well protected highly featured face on solid rock. I felt this would make a great beginner's lead.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a two bolt anchor.

content.description: A small natural rock arch graces the belay at the top of this route. You can easily walk off this route to the right (NNE - or on to set a toprope). A decent route too, an optional nut placement just off the deck leads to the first bolt. From here either climb the groove to the left or the fin to the right of the bolts.  You'll find a very easy 15-20 foot runout from the last bolt to the anchor.
content.protection: Optional small not prior to first bolt, five bolts, and two bolt anchor.

content.description: This is a nice, thin, slabby route up the SE face of Barnacle Rock, just uphill from Bride and Groom on Wedding Rock. Scramble up on the ledge, and tiptoe to the first bolt. The rock has very interesting texture, featured with many tiny bumps.  Higher up you'll climb just to the left of the wild quartz 'barnacles.'
content.protection: Five bolts to two bolt anchor.

content.description:
Start immediately east of the huge flake wedged between wedding rock and the short fin to the south.

Large flakes diminish and yield to thin crimps as you approach the second bolt. This is the crux. Sustained and vertical climbing eventually eases as the route merges with Bride. Cruise to the anchors, and enjoy the view!
content.protection: Four bolts to a two bolt anchor.  The last bolt and anchor are shared with Bride just to the left (W).
content.location:
This route lies just to the right (East) of

Bride

on Wedding Rock.

content.description:
Clip the fist bolt from the slab, then step down and hop on. Crimps, edges, and steep climbing on compact, fine grained rock make this a beatiful route.  It shares the last bolt and anchors with

Groom

(5.9) to the right. It is pumpy and steep for the grade. Watch out for a few loose flakes and holds at the start.
content.protection: 5 bolts.
content.location: Bride is the left route on Wedding Rock in the Lion's Den.

content.description: When approaching the Bear Hug Spire, turn to your right to view a checkerboard wall. Arete climbs the bolted line to the two bolt anchor. Bring a sling for a horn and/or a medium hex for after the last bolt. Or just try your luck and run it out.
content.protection: 5 bolts, some pro, to anchors.

content.description: Bearhug climbs a gently overhaning prow - a nice looking line and well worth doing.  Located uphill from Wedding and Barnacle rocks and just downhill from Lion's Mane.  Climb up the easy slab on the left to the first bolt, followed by some easy 5.10 climbing. The climbing on the prow proper is fun, pumpy and balancy. Well bolted, great moves, and decent rock, I just wish it were longer.
content.protection: Six bolts to lowering chains.
